addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham Knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

9 Jan
n
1589
From m
r
Bodley from the
Hage
e
privie Counsell
established about
C. Maurice
.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. in my former letters, w
t
whiche
e messenger departed three daies sins, I
have advertised yo
r
H. of divers particularities.
Among others, of
e Hollanders intention, to ordene a
Councell to be alwaies attendant on Count Maurice:
whiche, as I understand, is already concluded, and
there are 5. elected,
Egmont,
that was in
En-
gland
, one of
e Pauli of
Dordrecht
,
Clant
of
Am-
sterdame
, and
Docto
r
Francis
of North
Holland
:
e name of
e fiveth I can not yet learne.
Moreover
e Count taketh his jorney very shortly
towardes
Zeland
, where it is thought, that the
States of
at Province wilbe dealt w
t
all, to depute
two more, in their owne behalf, to
e said number.
I am fully persuaded,
at there is some kinde of
alteration towardes in this government: but it is
kept so secret, from me in speciall as I can not
conjecture, nor any of those w
t
whome I talke,
wherto it will tend. Howe inconvenient it is,
at
any suche notable innovation should be made w
t
out
her
Ma
ties
privitie, or notice at lest of
e
Councell
of State
, of w
ch
e Count is a member, I leave to
be considered of by yo
r
H. Heere is
one
Agileus
come lately out of England, who
in my
L. of Leicesters
time was Procuro
r
General
of Utrecht. He was no sooner arrived at
e
Hage, but
e Advocat Fiscall of Holland laid
handes uppon him, and examined him very strictly
about
e cause of his being in England, willing
him to sette it downe in writing, which he hath per-
fourmed accordingly: and what further course
they intend to take w
t
him, I knowe not. For the
fol.23v
partie himself nether knoweth, nor can imagine
any thing, wherew
t
they can charge him. Only he
suspecteth
at they are gelouse of his doinges, by reason
of some familiaritie betweene him and
Deventer
.
Uppon this occasion, understanding w
t
in these
two daies, that Deventer was arrived at
Rote-
rodame
, w
t
intention to come to
e Hage, I caused
his frindes to send him worde of this proceeding
w
t
Agileus, and to persuade him to looke for no-
thing heere but rigourous intertenment. The re-
porte is abroad that he bringeth letters from her
Ma
tie
but having no certeintie of it, I can give
him no advise, about his comming to this towne.
Heerw
t
I send yo
r
H. a copie
of a letter
w
ch
I have
gotten translated out of dutche, being written
by Deventer out of England to
Count Hollocke
,
wherew
t
e Count would seeme to be highly offended
and theruppon, to please Count Maurice and the
states, for I can see no other cause, hath sent
e
letter unto them, w
ch
no dout, being construed to
e worst, hath augmented their hatred against
him. Of
Lieutenant Throg-
morton
, by whome I send yo
r
H. this letter, I
would signifie w
at
I heare, in respect of his ho-
nest conversation, and of his valew, but I
knowe
S
r
Francis Vere
, who hath bin an eye witnes
of sundrie his good desertes, will doe it more
effectually. Nevertheles I can not but recom-
mend to yo
r
H. his vertuous inclination, w
ch
is
wholy bent, as he himself protesteth, and other
men judge by his actions, to remove that infamie
and dishono
r
, wherew
t
his familie hath bin lately
touched, by some extraordinary endevo
r
in
doing service to her Ma
tie
.
fol.24r
I doe nowe understand
at Deventer, uppon
e
warning of his frindes, is gone to
e
Brille
: and
he hath sent me worde,
at I shall heare from him
presently, concerning his buisnes. And untill I
knowe in w
at
sort he commeth armed from her Ma
tie
I can not helpe him w
t
any direction.
Thus I
take my h
u
ble leave. From
e Hage.
Ja
n
19. 89.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
